awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Experimental tests of alternative states on rocky intertidal shores.
awd_abstract_narration:
Unexpected events that tip an ecosystem from one type of community to another are poorly understood yet often have serious ecological and economic effects, exemplified by the sudden collapse of productive grasslands into desert in the southwestern US. This project will investigate the underlying causes of the switch between alternative communities, dominated by either seaweeds or mussels, on sheltered rocky shores in the Gulf of Maine.  A unique long-term experiment will advance general understanding of the resilience of natural communities to ecological perturbations of different sizes, the extent to which ecological transitions are reversible when environmental conditions are restored, and the predictability of ecological communities when perturbed.  The research team includes a high school teacher from Maine who has a long association with this project. Six to eight of her students will participate in the field research each year, and the teacher will develop classroom activities appropriate for high school students and K-12 teachers. Primary data, panoramic photographs of the experimental plots, and educational activities will be available electronically, and the investigators will post a YouTube video on data archiving and management. 

The researchers will test hypotheses that (1) switches between alternative community states of mussel beds and rockweed stands occur in response to infrequent, large-scale occurrences of ice scour during winter, (2) the community that becomes established in large clearings made by ice scour is not predictable, (3) the order of species arrival during re-establishment drives community development and (4) the alternative communities are stable. These hypotheses will be tested using a Before-After-Control-Impact (BACI) design consisting of experimental clearings of different sizes, uncleared controls that were created in 1996-97, and half of these controls that were cleared again in 2010-11. In addition to collecting data characterizing patterns of succession in these developing communities, the researchers will assay rates of predation on mussels, mortality rates of mussels in patches of different sizes, and recruitment of juveniles of four key species annually. Analyses of data will compare outcomes from the first run of the experiment (1997-2008) with those from the second run (2011-2021) to test if community development is predictable. The approach of repeating an experiment to test for alternative community states in a natural ecosystem is unique and has broad implications for studies of alternative states in other ecosystems.

por.por_cntn:
The principal goal of the project was to test by experiment if different assemblages of species characterized either by abundant barnacles and mussels, or different species of fucoid algae (rockweeds) could, in turn, occupy the very same sites on sheltered rocky shores in the Gulf of Maine. Occurrence of different ecological communities at the same sites at different times implies that natural ecosystems can have multiple stable community states for a given environment. We hypothesized that the potential for switches among community states increased with, both, the magnitude of environmental perturbation (in this study, mimicking winter ice scour along the shoreline) and variability of ecological dynamics in time, like survivorship of individuals and their offspring in populations.

 

Switches among fucoid and barnacle-mussel communities on sheltered rocky shores were associated with mimicking ice scour >12m2. Communities of rockweeds in experimental clearings <4m2 were resilient to removal recovering within 2 generations. In larger clearings (>12 m2), outcomes of changes of community state varied, consistent with the expectation that switches between communities may be historically contingent. Plots that previously switched from rockweeds to mussels were not recolonized again by mussels following a second simulated ice scour. Changing oceanic condition over 20 years in the Gulf of Maine, especially ocean warming, is associated with declines in mussel populations throughout the region. We documented a 15% decline per year in recruitment of juvenile mussels to populations, resulting in mussels becoming rare on intertidal shores in the Gulf of Maine. Over the same period, declines in abundances of common species of snails and barnacles of 3 to 5% per year were observed.

 

Variability across years in species abundances, rates of recruitment (establishment of offspring) and mortality of individuals was great thereby facilitating changes of community state. Large clearings on shores exposed to waves and water motion showed persistent change from one fucoid algal species to another after 27 years consistent with it representing an alternative state on rocky shores. However, in same-sized clearings on shores with little water motion this same fucoid alga was a long transient stage during ecological succession that eventually returned to the original community state, similar in composition and abundance to control plots.

 

The results of the project underscore the important role that variability of ecological processes in space and time and historical contingency play in determining outcomes of the assembly of natural communities. This research also emphasizes the long time frames of observation required to distinguish among alternative stable, endpoint states of communities and long transient ecological stages that eventually yield to the original endpoint state. One implication of long, slow dynamics on rocky shores is that ecologists should shift focus to understanding the ecology of transient stages with less attention paid to stable, endpoint states that may not occur until well into the future, to better manage rapidly changing ecosystems far from equilibrium in the present.

 

The broader impacts of the project were focused on 3 areas; student training, K-12 education, and public outreach. The project trained 1 undergraduate student (a Hispanic female) and 4 Master’s level graduate students (2 males and 2 females, one an African-American student) in field and laboratory skills in biology and ecology.

 

Educational outreach to K-12 students involved exploring themes of ecological change in ecosystems through time. Presentations to primary school students emphasized hands-on activities including touch-tanks with living organisms. Lesson plans included discussions with students in which they were asked to predict how distributions of organisms might change with sea level rise and warming seas. Lesson plans developed for middle school students used historical and contemporary photographs of the Los Angeles basin watershed to explore its past, present and future emphasizing uses and engineering of the Los Angeles River. Educational outreach to high school students was led by the project’s research associate, a high school teacher and Maine Master Naturalist. Each year of the project, notwithstanding three years associated with the pandemic, nine 11th grade students (36 in total throughout the project) accompanied by 2 high school teachers were brought to the project field sites in Maine. Students were trained in field sampling techniques in ecology and developed skills through an outdoor education curriculum. The value of this program to parents and students at the high school resulted in a commitment to continue it following project termination.

 

Outreach to the general public emerged from the project contributing to, and participating in, production of the California Seaweed Festival. This annual festival is designed to educate the public about the uses and value of seaweeds in nature and society through a celebration of seaweeds in farming, science, food, product innovation, art and culture. The project contributed to production of four festivals (one online during the pandemic and three in-person events) between 2020 and 2023, with over 2000 attendees in 2023 when the project terminated.
